user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of need_100_continue:
```c
static bool
need_100_continue (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  const char *expect;

  if (! MHD_IS_HTTP_VER_1_1_COMPAT (connection->rq.http_ver))
    return false;

  if (0 == connection->rq.remaining_upload_size)
    return false;

  if (MHD_NO ==
      MHD_lookup_connection_value_n (connection,
                                     MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                     MHD_HTTP_HEADER_EXPECT,
                                     MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ( \
                                       MHD_HTTP_HEADER_EXPECT),
                                     &expect,
                                     NULL))
    return false;

  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (expect,
                               "100-continue"))
    return true;

  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No direct use of memcmp appears in the provided code. The other fragments are simple checks (version, remaining_upload_size) or calls that pass explicit lengths (MHD_lookup_connection_value_n with MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_), so they do not indicate comparing null-terminated strings via memcmp. The only place that performs a string comparison of a runtime string against a string literal is the call to MHD_str_equal_caseless_(expect, "100-continue"), which should be investigated because its implementation could use memcmp on null-terminated strings. All other lines do not perform string comparisons that could violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 and therefore do not need investigation.
